misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No misconception detected (correct parallel-array sorting and selection)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array and swapping the corresponding names at the same time will keep the name-score pairing correct, and that after sorting ascending, the last element is the maximum (top student).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No gap observed. This matches Java’s execution model: arrays are mutable, swaps update the arrays in place, and after an ascending sort the maximum score is at index n-1 (for n>0).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None for valid inputs (N > 0 and correctly provided names/scores). Output matches the required behavior for the sample run.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes there will always be at least one student, so accessing names[n-1] and scores[n-1] is always safe.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed and accessing index -1 (when n==0) throws an exception. If the problem statement/tests allow N=0, the program needs a guard before using n-1.
